message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: TouringMachines: an architecture for dynamic, rational, mobile agents
Paper Abstract: It is becoming widely accepted that neither purely reactive nor purely deliberative control techniques are capable of producing the range of behaviours required of intelligent computational or robotic agents in dynamic, unpredictable, multi-agent worlds. We present a new architecture for controlling autonomous, mobile agents – building on previous work addressing reactive and deliberative control methods. The proposed multi-layered control architecture allows a resource-bounded, goal-directed agent to react promptly to unexpected changes in its environment; at the same time it enables the agent to reason predictively about potential conflicts by constructing and projecting causal models or theories which hypothesise other agents’ goals and intentions. The line of research adopted is very much a pragmatic one. A single, common architecture has been implemented which, being extensively parametrized, allows an experimenter to study functionally- and behaviourally-diverse agent configurations. A principal aim of this research is to understand the role different functional capabilities play in constraining an agent’s behaviour under varying environmental conditions. To this end, we have constructed an experimental testbed comprising a simulated multi-agent world in which a variety of agent configurations and behaviours have been investigated. Experience with the new control architecture is described.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Multi-Agent System

Here are the key findings from the search results:

### Definition
A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

### Purpose and Advantages
Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Components and Characteristics
Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. The agents involved can vary in nature: Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

Key characteristics include: Autonomy: agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous. Decentralization: no agent is designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).

### Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Recent Developments
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. The agents involved can vary in nature: Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

### Applications
Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Recent Developments
With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous agency theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agency_theory"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Automated negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_negotiation"},{"title":"AutoGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AutoGPT"},{"title":"Manus (AI agent) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manus_(AI_agent)"},{"title":"Cooperative distributed problem solving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_distributed_problem_solving"}]

Here's what I found about autonomous agents:

## Definition

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)A system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

## Key Characteristics

Key attributes include complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.(no content)Common concepts include persistence, autonomy, social ability, and reactivity - agents perceive the context in which they operate and react to it appropriately.

## Modern Applications

Autonomous agents increasingly interact with IoT devices, enabling smart home systems, industrial monitoring, and urban infrastructure management.(no content)Tools like Cognition AI's Devin aim to create autonomous software engineers capable of complex reasoning, planning, and completing engineering tasks requiring thousands of decisions.

## Recent Examples

AutoGPT is an open-source autonomous software agent that uses OpenAI's large language models, such as GPT-4, to attempt to achieve a goal specified by a user in natural language. Unlike chatbots that require continuous user commands, AutoGPT works autonomously by breaking the main goal into smaller sub-tasks and using tools like web browsing and file management to complete them.

Web search results for query: "Reactive control"

Links: [{"title":"Voltage control and reactive power management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_control_and_reactive_power_management"},{"title":"Reaction control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaction_control_system"},{"title":"Ancillary services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancillary_services_(electric_power)"},{"title":"Unified power flow controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_power_flow_controller"},{"title":"Occupant-centric building controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupant-centric_building_controls"},{"title":"Subsumption architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsumption_architecture"},{"title":"Reactive programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_programming"},{"title":"Robotic paradigm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_paradigm"},{"title":"Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Static VAR compensator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_Power_Control_Relay"}]

Based on the web search results, "Reactive Control" refers to different concepts depending on the context:

## General Definition

Reactive control uses real-time occupant preference and presents feedback to immediately alter the conditions of a space.

## In Building Control Systems

In occupant-centric building controls, reactive control is one approach that uses real-time occupant preference and presents feedback to immediately alter the conditions of the space. However, reactive control is not ideal for systems with slow response times such as HVAC.

## In Robotics

In robotics, reactive control is a key concept: The reactive paradigm describes a bottom-up control structure in which the robot's actions emerge from direct interactions between the robot's sensors and behaviors, without relying on a central plan or world model. Additionally, most behavior-based systems are also reactive, which means they need no programming of what a chair looks like, or what kind of surface the robot is moving on. Instead, all the information is gleaned from the input of the robot's sensors, and the robot uses that information to gradually correct its actions according to the changes in immediate environment.

## In Electrical Power Systems

In electrical engineering, a static VAR compensator (SVC) is a set of electrical devices for providing fast-acting reactive power on high-voltage electricity transmission networks, and SVCs are part of the flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) device family.

Links: [{"title":"Voltage control and reactive power management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_control_and_reactive_power_management"},{"title":"Reaction control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaction_control_system"},{"title":"Ancillary services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancillary_services_(electric_power)"},{"title":"Unified power flow controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_power_flow_controller"},{"title":"Occupant-centric building controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupant-centric_building_controls"},{"title":"Subsumption architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsumption_architecture"},{"title":"Reactive programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_programming"},{"title":"Robotic paradigm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_paradigm"},{"title":"Behavior-based robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-based_robotics"},{"title":"Static VAR compensator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_Power_Control_Relay"}]

Based on the web search results, "Reactive Control" refers to different concepts depending on the context:

## General Definition

Reactive control uses real-time occupant preference and presents feedback to immediately alter the conditions of a space.

## In Building Control Systems

In occupant-centric building controls, reactive control is one approach that uses real-time occupant preference and presents feedback to immediately alter the conditions of the space. However, reactive control is not ideal for systems with slow response times such as HVAC.

## In Robotics

In robotics, reactive control is a key concept: The reactive paradigm describes a bottom-up control structure in which the robot's actions emerge from direct interactions between the robot's sensors and behaviors, without relying on a central plan or world model. Additionally, most behavior-based systems are also reactive, which means they need no programming of what a chair looks like, or what kind of surface the robot is moving on. Instead, all the information is gleaned from the input of the robot's sensors, and the robot uses that information to gradually correct its actions according to the changes in immediate environment.

## In Electrical Power Systems

In electrical engineering, a static VAR compensator (SVC) is a set of electrical devices for providing fast-acting reactive power on high-voltage electricity transmission networks, and SVCs are part of the flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) device family.

Links: [{"title":"Deliberative democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_democracy"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Robotic paradigm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_paradigm"},{"title":"Deliberative process privilege - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_process_privilege"},{"title":"Thinking, Fast and Slow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thinking,_Fast_and_Slow"},{"title":"Embedded democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embedded_democracy"},{"title":"Deliberation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberation"},{"title":"Deliberative assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_assembly"},{"title":"Types of democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Types_of_democracy"},{"title":"Representative democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representative_democracies"}]

Based on the search results, I found several different contexts where "deliberative control" relates to different domains:

## Deliberative Control in Robotics

In robotics, the hierarchical or deliberative paradigm describes a top-down control structure in which the robot's actions are driven by explicit planning, with the robot following a sense-plan-act sequence.(no content)At each step, the robot collects sensory information, updates an internal model of the world and determines the next action based on the model.

## Deliberative Control in AI/Agents

A deliberative agent is defined as "one that possesses an explicitly represented, symbolic model of the world, and in which decisions (for example about what actions to perform) are made via symbolic reasoning".(no content)Deliberative agents maintain a symbolic representation of the world they inhabit and possess an internal image of the external environment, making them capable to plan their actions.

## Deliberation in General Context

More broadly, deliberation is a process of thoughtfully weighing options and emphasizes the use of logic and reason as opposed to power-struggle, creativity, or dialogue.

The specific meaning of "deliberative control" depends on the context in which it's being discussed—whether in robotics, artificial intelligence, psychology, or other domains.

Web search results for query: "Causal model"

Links: [{"title":"Causal model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_model"},{"title":"Rubin causal model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubin_causal_model"},{"title":"Causal inference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_inference"},{"title":"Causal pie model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_pie_model"},{"title":"Causal AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_AI"},{"title":"Bayesian structural time series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_structural_time_series"},{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Path analysis (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Path_analysis_(statistics)"},{"title":"Logic model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_model"},{"title":"Structural equation modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_equation_modeling"}]

Here are the search results for "Causal model":

## Definition

A causal model (also called a structural causal model) is a conceptual model that represents the causal mechanisms of a system.

## Key Features

Causal models often employ formal causal notation, such as structural equation modeling or causal directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), to describe relationships among variables and to guide inference.(no content)By clarifying which variables should be included, excluded, or controlled for, causal models can improve the design of empirical studies and the interpretation of results.

## Applications and Benefits

Causal models can enable researchers to answer some causal questions using observational data, reducing the need for interventional studies such as randomized controlled trials. In cases where randomized experiments are impractical or unethical—for example, when studying the effects of environmental exposures or social determinants of health—causal models provide a framework for drawing valid conclusions from non-experimental data.(no content)Causal models have found applications in signal processing, epidemiology, machine learning, cultural studies, and urbanism, and they can describe both linear and nonlinear processes.

## Historical Background

In 1921 Wright's path analysis became the theoretical ancestor of causal modeling and causal graphs. He developed this approach while attempting to untangle the relative impacts of heredity, development and environment on guinea pig coat patterns.

## Related Approaches

Common frameworks for causal inference include the causal pie model (component-cause), Pearl's structural causal model (causal diagram + do-calculus), structural equation modeling, and Rubin causal model (potential-outcome).

I've completed a web search on "Robotics" and found comprehensive information about the field. Here are some key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components of Robot Design

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work to create robot systems: Mechanical construction, Electrical components that power and control the machinery, and Software.

## Types of Robots

The field encompasses a diverse range of robots. Robots can be autonomous or semi-autonomous and range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.

## Emerging Subfields

Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.(no content)In contrast to rigid-bodied robots built from metals, ceramics and hard plastics, the compliance of soft robots can improve their safety when working in close contact with humans.

The search results provided information from multiple sources including general definitions, specific robot types, and companies working in the robotics field.

I've completed a web search on "Robotics" and found comprehensive information about the field. Here are some key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components of Robot Design

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work to create robot systems: Mechanical construction, Electrical components that power and control the machinery, and Software.

## Types of Robots

The field encompasses a diverse range of robots. Robots can be autonomous or semi-autonomous and range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.

## Emerging Subfields

Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.(no content)In contrast to rigid-bodied robots built from metals, ceramics and hard plastics, the compliance of soft robots can improve their safety when working in close contact with humans.

The search results provided information from multiple sources including general definitions, specific robot types, and companies working in the robotics field.

Links: [{"title":"Intention - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intention"},{"title":"Belief–desire–intention software model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief–desire–intention_software_model"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Action (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Promise theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Promise_theory"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agency (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agency_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Action theory (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_theory_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Agent detection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent_detection"},{"title":"Self-agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-agency"}]

## Agent Intention - Search Results

I've completed a web search for "Agent intention." Here's what I found:

### Key Concepts

**What is an Intention?**

Intentions are mental states that involve action plans to which the agent has committed themselves.(no content)As action plans, they can guide behavior, with the action plan constituting the content of the intention while the commitment is the agent's attitude towards this content.

**Types of Intentions**

Prospective intentions, also known as "prior intentions", involve plans for the future and can be subdivided according to how far they plan ahead: proximal intentions involve plans for what one wants to do straightaway whereas distal intentions are concerned with a more remote future.(no content)Immediate intentions, on the other hand, are intentions that guide the agent while they are performing the action in question.

**Agent Intention in Computing**

In artificial intelligence, intentions represent the deliberative state of the agent – what the agent has chosen to do, and are desires to which the agent has to some extent committed.(no content)The belief–desire–intention software model (BDI) is a software model developed for programming intelligent agents.

**Role in Action**

Intentions are responsible for initiating, sustaining, and terminating actions and are frequently used to explain why people engage in a certain behavior.

Web search results for query: "Agent architecture"

Links: [{"title":"Agent architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent_architecture"},{"title":"Open Agent Architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Agent_Architecture"},{"title":"Deliberative agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliberative_agent"},{"title":"Subsumption architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subsumption_architecture"},{"title":"CLARION (cognitive architecture) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CLARION_(cognitive_architecture)"},{"title":"Cougaar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cougaar"},{"title":"Blackboard system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackboard_system"},{"title":"Architecture of Wales - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_of_Wales"},{"title":"Space-based architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space-based_architecture"},{"title":"Message delivery agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mail_delivery_agent"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of agent architecture:

## Definition

Agent architecture in computer science is a blueprint for software agents and intelligent control systems, depicting the arrangement of components.(no content)The architectures implemented by intelligent agents are referred to as cognitive architectures.

## Major Types of Agent Architectures

### Deliberative Agents
Deliberative agents maintain a symbolic representation of the world they inhabit and possess an internal image of the external environment, making them capable of planning their actions.(no content)The most commonly used architecture for implementing such behavior is a Belief–Desire–Intention (BDI) software model, where an agent's beliefs about the world, desires (goal) and intentions are internally represented and practical reasoning is applied to decide which action to select.

### Reactive Agents
Reactive agents are able to reach their goal only by reacting reflexively on external stimuli.(no content)Subsumption architecture is a reactive robotic architecture heavily associated with behavior-based robotics which was very popular in the 1980s and 90s, with the term introduced by Rodney Brooks and colleagues in 1986.

### Hybrid Agents
There has been considerable research focused on integrating both reactive and deliberative agent strategies resulting in developing a compound called hybrid agent, which combines extensive manipulation with nontrivial symbolic structures and reflexive reactive responses to the external event.

## Specific Implementations

Cougaar (acronym of Cognitive Agent Architecture) is a Java agent architecture with an open source that includes infrastructure and core services.(no content)CLARION is a computational cognitive architecture that has been used to simulate many domains and tasks in cognitive psychology and social psychology, as well as implementing intelligent systems in artificial intelligence applications.

I've completed a web search for "Artificial intelligence planning". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Key Concepts and Approaches

**Planning Methods:** Artificial action selection mechanisms can be divided into several categories: symbol-based systems sometimes known as classical planning, distributed solutions, and reactive or dynamic planning.

**Planning Algorithms:** Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995 and takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

**Problem Formulation:** The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence planning languages, first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998.(no content)PDDL is a human-readable format for problems in automated planning that gives a description of the possible states of the world, a description of the set of possible actions, a specific initial state of the world, and a specific set of desired goals.

**Application Domains:** Typical examples of domains are block-stacking, logistics, workflow management, and robot task planning.

I've completed a web search for "Artificial intelligence planning". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Key Concepts and Approaches

**Planning Methods:** Artificial action selection mechanisms can be divided into several categories: symbol-based systems sometimes known as classical planning, distributed solutions, and reactive or dynamic planning.

**Planning Algorithms:** Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995 and takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

**Problem Formulation:** The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence planning languages, first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998.(no content)PDDL is a human-readable format for problems in automated planning that gives a description of the possible states of the world, a description of the set of possible actions, a specific initial state of the world, and a specific set of desired goals.

**Application Domains:** Typical examples of domains are block-stacking, logistics, workflow management, and robot task planning.

## Analysis Complete ✓

I've successfully analyzed the "TouringMachines: an architecture for dynamic, rational, mobile agents" paper and extracted 10 key technical entities:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: contribution (the paper proposes a novel multi-layered control architecture)

### Key Entities Extracted
1. **Autonomous agent** (concept) - proposes new architecture for controlling these
2. **Behavior-based robotics** (method) - uses as foundational approach
3. **Deliberative agent** (concept) - combines with reactive control
4. **Mobile robot** (concept) - addresses control for mobile agents
5. **Multi-agent system** (task) - tackles multi-agent coordination
6. **Agent architecture** (concept) - proposes novel hybrid architecture
7. **Automated planning and scheduling** (method) - uses for predictive reasoning
8. **Causal model** (concept) - uses to predict agent behavior
9. **Intention** (concept) - uses for goal inference
10. **Robotics** (task) - overall research domain
